title: About Me
text:
The ‚ÄúControl‚Äù Problem
My journey into Virtual Reality (VR) began with a frustration that every experimental psychologist eventually faces: The Trade-Off.
During my PhD at Victoria University of Wellington, I was investigating Theory of Mind‚Äîhow we understand the intentions of others. Like many before me, I found myself stuck between two imperfect choices. I could run highly controlled experiments on a computer screen (which lacked the messy reality of actual human interaction), or I could run field studies (which had ‚Äúecological validity‚Äù but were impossible to control scientifically).
For years, this disconnect seemed intractable. We were studying human behavior by removing the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù and the ‚Äúbehavior‚Äù from the equation.


The ‚ÄúAccidental‚Äù Pivot
By complete chance, I stumbled upon a basic VR setup being tested in our department. I realized almost immediately that this technology wasn‚Äôt just a gimmick for gamers; it was the solution to the Trade-Off.
VR allowed me to place participants in ‚Äúreal‚Äù situations‚Äîstanding at the edge of a cliff, walking a plank, or interacting with a virtual agent‚Äîwhile maintaining millisecond-level control over every photon of light they saw.
I pivoted my research focus entirely. I taught myself Unity and C#, not because I wanted to be a developer, but because I needed better tools to answer scientific questions. This work culminated in my research on Presence‚Äîunderstanding not just if people feel fear in VR, but why they treat virtual threats as real.


Open Science & Reproducibility
As I built more complex simulations, I realized another problem: Reproducibility.
A text-based methods section in a PDF cannot possibly capture the complexity of a VR environment. If I say ‚Äúthe participant stood on a ledge,‚Äù how high was it? How was the lighting? What was the physics engine doing?
This realization turned me into a fierce advocate for Open Science. I believe that code is the method. Today, I publish my datasets, analysis code (R/Python), and VR environments (Unity) openly. I advocate for a science where ‚Äúreplicating a study‚Äù means downloading the environment and hitting ‚ÄòPlay‚Äô.


Current Work
Today, I wear three hats: 1. Lecturer: Teaching the next generation of psychologists how to use these tools. 2. Researcher: Investigating emotion regulation and the ‚ÄúSense of Presence.‚Äù 3. Consultant: Helping other labs and companies build valid, reliable, and rigorous VR experiments.
If you are interested in discussing experimental design, VR development, or data analysis, please get in touch.

title: Research
text:
My research program is driven by a single, overarching goal: to establish a rigorous science of human behavior in simulated environments.
For decades, psychology has faced a ‚Äúvalidity trade-off.‚Äù We could study behavior in the real world (high ecological validity, low control) or in the lab (low ecological validity, high control). My work demonstrates that Virtual Reality (VR) allows us to break this trade-off, enabling us to study complex, high-stakes emotional experiences‚Äîlike fear, awe, and disgust‚Äîwithout sacrificing millisecond-level experimental precision.

title: Research
text:
Core Research Areas

1. The Nature of Presence
What makes a virtual experience feel ‚Äúreal‚Äù?
My recent work challenges the traditional ‚Äúbottom-up‚Äù view that physiological arousal drives the sense of presence. In our recent paper in Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, we demonstrated that subjective fear‚Äînot physiological arousal‚Äîshapes the experience of presence.
Using a high-fidelity ‚ÄúVirtual Plank‚Äù simulation, we dissociated these two systems. This supports constructionist theories of emotion (e.g., Lisa Feldman Barrett), suggesting that ‚ÄúPresence‚Äù is a top-down cognitive conceptualization, not just a visceral reaction to sensory input.






Key Finding



‚ÄúPresence is not just about higher resolution graphics; it is about the meaning the user assigns to the environment. If the brain constructs a threat narrative, the environment becomes ‚Äòreal,‚Äô regardless of heart rate.‚Äù




2. Emotion Regulation Under Threat
How do we regulate fear when the threat feels immediate?
Traditional labs study fear using static images on a computer screen. But looking at a picture of a spider is fundamentally different from standing on a ledge 80 floors up.
I use VR to induce high-intensity threat states in the lab. My ‚ÄúVirtual Plank‚Äù and ‚ÄúFilthy Bathroom‚Äù (Disgust) paradigms allow us to test: * Inhibitory Control: Does fear paralyze us or speed us up? (See my work on the Stop Signal Task on a plank). * Reappraisal vs.¬†Suppression: Can you ‚Äúthink‚Äù your way out of fear when your visual system is screaming ‚Äúdanger‚Äù? * Physiological Synchrony: How do EEG and EDA signals align with behavioral freezing?


3. Methodological Innovation
Standardizing the ‚ÄúVR Neuroscience Lab‚Äù
A major barrier to adoption is the technical complexity of setting up a VR lab. My paper ‚ÄúLaunching Your VR Neuroscience Laboratory‚Äù serves as a blueprint for other researchers. I am committed to Open Science: * Open Assets: I release the Unity environments for my tasks so others can replicate them exactly. * Open Code: Data analysis pipelines (R/Python) are shared to ensure reproducibility.

text:
Future Vision: The Simulation Science Lab
My long-term aim is to establish a dedicated Simulation Science Laboratory. This facility will move beyond simple HMD setups to fully integrated multi-modal simulation, combining:

Wireless EEG & Mobile fNIRS for neural imaging in motion.
Full-body Motion Capture for behavioral kinematics.
Haptic Feedback to ‚Äúclose the loop‚Äù of sensory immersion.

This lab will not just study VR; it will use VR as a tool to understand the fundamental mechanisms of the predictive brain.

title: Statistical Power & The Tides
text:
One of the hardest concepts for psychology students to grasp is Statistical Power.
We teach them definitions like ‚Äú1 - beta‚Äù or ‚Äúthe probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false.‚Äù These definitions are accurate, but they are intuitive dead ends. They don‚Äôt help a student visualize why their experiment failed.
Instead, I prefer to teach Power using the metaphor of The Tides.

title: Statistical Power & The Tides
text:
The Rock and The Water
Imagine you are standing on a cliff looking down at a turbulent ocean. Your goal is simple: Spot the Rock.
In this metaphor: * The Rock is your Effect Size. It is the real phenomenon you are trying to find. * The Water is the Noise (measurement error, individual differences). * The Tide Level is your Statistical Power.

Scenario A: Low Power (High Tide)
Imagine the tide is incredibly high. The water is deep and choppy. Somewhere beneath those waves, there is a rock. It is definitely there (the effect exists!), but the noise of the water is completely covering it.
You look for an hour and see nothing. You conclude: ‚ÄúThere is no rock here.‚Äù In statistics, we call this a Type II Error (False Negative). The rock didn‚Äôt vanish; you just lacked the power to see it through the noise.


Scenario B: High Power (Low Tide)
Now, imagine we lower the tide. The water level drops. The waves settle. Suddenly, the jagged tip of the rock breaks the surface. You didn‚Äôt make the rock bigger; you just removed the noise that was hiding it.
This is what happens when we increase sample size or reduce measurement error (e.g., using a precise VR tracker instead of a stopwatch). We lower the water level so the signal becomes visible.

title: Statistical Power & The Tides
text:
The ‚ÄúBig Rock‚Äù Fallacy
Many researchers try to fix a ‚ÄúHigh Tide‚Äù problem by looking for a ‚ÄúBigger Rock.‚Äù
They think: ‚ÄúIf I just make my manipulation stronger (a louder noise, a scarier VR cliff), the effect will be massive, and I‚Äôll see it even if my sample is small.‚Äù
This works‚Ä¶ sometimes. If the rock is a mountain, you will see it even at high tide. But most effects in psychology aren‚Äôt mountains; they are pebbles. We are looking for subtle changes in reaction time or slight shifts in emotion regulation.
If you are looking for a pebble at high tide, no amount of squinting (p-hacking) will save you. You need to drain the water.

title: Statistical Power & The Tides
text:
Why Simulation Matters
This is why I advocate for Simulation Science.
In a traditional field study, the ‚Äúweather‚Äù is unpredictable. The waves are choppy (high noise). In a Virtual Reality lab, I control the weather. I can turn off the wind. I can perfectly standardize the environment.
By using VR, we are essentially building a breakwall around our study. We calm the waters, reducing the noise variance, which makes even small rocks visible.
We don‚Äôt need ‚Äúbigger‚Äù effects; we need calmer water.
